secText:
Essential Question:
How do engines use heat to do work?

Enduring Understandings:
1. [OBJ:expsec_l059:Engines] use energy to do work. Engines complete repeating cycles to do work. Engines are not 100% efficient.
2. [OBJ:expsec_l060:Heat engines] are used as models of real-world engines. Heat is transferred into the engine, causing work to be done. Heat also flows out of the engine, which contributes to the engine not being 100% efficient.
3. In an engine, the [OBJ:expsec_l061:work done by the engine] is equal to the net heat transfer to the engine.
4. [OBJ:expsec_l078:Heat pumps] and [OBJ:expsec_l077:refrigerators] are examples of engines. Refrigerators force heat from a colder environment into a warmer environment. Heat pumps transfer heat from a warmer environment into a colder environment.
